title: If someone was starving and wasn’t eating, and they hypothetically ate something the day before they would have died, would they survive? - Quora

response.answer_text: When someone starves to death, their body shuts down. Merely eating “something” if they were literally on death’s door would not be enough to stop the downward spiral. The body, in all likelihood, would not be able to process the solid food. It would take hospitalization with lots of fluids and a gradual training of the body how to eat again- if they weren’t too far gone. Age and fitness level would definitely come into play in this scenario.
“If someone was starving and wasn’t eating, and he hypothetically ate something the day before he would have died, would he survive?” Honestly, dude, it's OK to use gender specific pronouns.

The self-defeating wording of your answer aside, short answer, probably not. Not quite as short answer: Zahrah Murdock's answer to Is it possible to survive if we eat something a minute before we die from starvation?

When you die of starvation it is because your organs have given up and stopped working from lack of a whole load of things they need. Eating again at the last moment won’t restart them, they have already stopped. Your stomach won’t produce enough acid to dissolve the food, your guts won’t let through enough nutrients, and besides the quantity you can swallow while you are dying is ridiculously small compared to the needs of your body.
